title: JavaIterators - Q0001
text: Which package contains the Iterator interface?
explanation: The Iterator interface is part of the java.util package.

title: JavaIterators - Q0002
text: Which of the following methods is defined in the Iterator interface?
explanation: The Iterator interface defines hasNext(), next(), and remove() methods.

title: JavaIterators - Q0003
text: What does the hasNext() method of Iterator return?

options.text: true if there are more elements to iterate
false if there are more elements

explanation: The hasNext() method returns true if the iteration has more elements.

title: JavaIterators - Q0004
text: What does the next() method of Iterator do?

options.text: Returns the next element in the iteration
Checks if there is a next element

explanation: The next() method returns the next element in the iteration.

title: JavaIterators - Q0005
text: What exception is thrown if next() is called when no more elements exist?
explanation: Calling next() when no elements remain throws NoSuchElementException.

title: JavaIterators - Q0006
text: Which method removes the last element returned by the iterator?
explanation: The remove() method removes the last element returned by the iterator.

title: JavaIterators - Q0007
text: What exception is thrown if remove() is called before next()?
explanation: Calling remove() before next() throws IllegalStateException.

title: JavaIterators - Q0008
text: Which of the following interfaces extends Iterator?
explanation: ListIterator extends Iterator and adds bidirectional traversal methods.

title: JavaIterators - Q0009
text: Which of the following methods is specific to ListIterator?
explanation: ListIterator adds methods like previous(), hasPrevious(), and add(E e).

title: JavaIterators - Q0010
text: Which of the following collections provide a ListIterator?
explanation: ArrayList, LinkedList, and Vector provide ListIterator implementations.

title: JavaIterators - Q0011
text: Which of the following is true about Iterator and fail-fast behavior?

options.text: Iterator throws ConcurrentModificationException if modified during iteration

explanation: Fail-fast iterators throw ConcurrentModificationException if the collection is modified during iteration.

title: JavaIterators - Q0012
text: Which of the following is a fail-safe iterator?
explanation: CopyOnWriteArrayList provides a fail-safe iterator that works on a copy of the collection.

title: JavaIterators - Q0013
text: Which of the following is true about fail-safe iterators?

options.text: They are slower than fail-fast iterators

explanation: Fail-safe iterators work on a copy of the collection and do not throw ConcurrentModificationException.

title: JavaIterators - Q0014
text: Which of the following is true about Enumeration and Iterator?

options.text: Enumeration is legacy, Iterator is modern

explanation: Enumeration is a legacy interface, while Iterator is the modern replacement.

title: JavaIterators - Q0015
text: Which of the following methods is not part of the Iterator interface?
explanation: The previous() method is part of ListIterator, not Iterator.

title: JavaIterators - Q0016
text: Which Java version introduced the forEachRemaining() method in Iterator?
explanation: The forEachRemaining() method was introduced in Java 8 to support lambda expressions.

title: JavaIterators - Q0017
text: What is the return type of the next() method in Iterator?
explanation: The next() method returns an Object, which can be cast to the appropriate type.

title: JavaIterators - Q0018
text: Which of the following is true about Iterator and Iterable?
explanation: The Iterable interface provides the iterator() method to return an Iterator.

title: JavaIterators - Q0019
text: Which of the following is true about the remove() method in Iterator?

options.text: It removes the last element returned by next()

explanation: The remove() method removes the last element returned by next().

title: JavaIterators - Q0020
text: Which of the following is true about Iterator and concurrent modification?
explanation: Fail-fast iterators throw ConcurrentModificationException when the collection is modified during iteration.

title: JavaIterators - Q0021
text: Which of the following is true about the Iterator interface?
explanation: Iterator is a generic interface that allows iteration over a collection of a specific type.

title: JavaIterators - Q0022
text: Which of the following is true about the Iterable interface?
explanation: The Iterable interface provides the iterator() method to return an Iterator.

title: JavaIterators - Q0023
text: Which of the following is true about the for-each loop in Java?
explanation: The enhanced for-each loop uses the Iterator internally to traverse elements.

title: JavaIterators - Q0024
text: Which of the following is true about ListIterator?

options.text: It is used only with Sets

explanation: ListIterator allows bidirectional traversal of lists.

title: JavaIterators - Q0025
text: Which of the following methods is unique to ListIterator?
explanation: ListIterator adds methods like set(), add(), and previous() for enhanced control.

title: JavaIterators - Q0026
text: Which of the following collections support ListIterator?
explanation: ArrayList, LinkedList, and Vector support ListIterator.

title: JavaIterators - Q0027
text: Which of the following is true about Spliterator?

options.text: It can traverse and partition elements
It is used only for Maps

explanation: Spliterator can traverse and partition elements for parallel processing.

title: JavaIterators - Q0028
text: Which Java version introduced Spliterator?
explanation: Spliterator was introduced in Java 8 to support parallel stream processing.

title: JavaIterators - Q0029
text: Which of the following methods is defined in Spliterator?
explanation: Spliterator defines methods like tryAdvance(), forEachRemaining(), and trySplit().

title: JavaIterators - Q0030
text: Which of the following is true about Enumeration?
explanation: Enumeration is a legacy interface used before Iterator was introduced.

title: JavaIterators - Q0031
text: Which of the following methods are defined in Enumeration?
explanation: Enumeration defines hasMoreElements() and nextElement() methods.

title: JavaIterators - Q0032
text: Which of the following is true about Iterator and Enumeration?

options.text: Iterator can remove elements, Enumeration cannot
Enumeration can remove elements, Iterator cannot

explanation: Iterator provides remove() method, while Enumeration does not.

title: JavaIterators - Q0033
text: Which of the following is true about fail-fast iterators?

options.text: They are slower than fail-safe iterators

explanation: Fail-fast iterators throw ConcurrentModificationException when the collection is modified.

title: JavaIterators - Q0034
text: Which of the following is true about fail-safe iterators?

options.text: They work on a copy of the collection
They are faster than fail-fast iterators

explanation: Fail-safe iterators work on a copy of the collection, avoiding exceptions.

title: JavaIterators - Q0035
text: Which of the following collections provide fail-safe iterators?
explanation: Concurrent collections like CopyOnWriteArrayList and ConcurrentHashMap provide fail-safe iterators.

title: JavaIterators - Q0036
text: Which of the following is true about Iterator and Streams?

options.text: Streams can be created from Iterators
Iterators can be created from Streams

explanation: Streams can be created from Iterators and vice versa using utility methods.

title: JavaIterators - Q0037
text: Which of the following is true about Iterator and thread safety?

options.text: Iterators are not thread-safe by default

explanation: Iterators are not thread-safe by default; concurrent modifications can cause exceptions.

title: JavaIterators - Q0038
text: Which of the following is true about Iterator and remove()?

options.text: remove() is optional and may throw UnsupportedOperationException

explanation: The remove() method is optional and may throw UnsupportedOperationException if not supported.

title: JavaIterators - Q0039
text: Which of the following is true about Iterator and generics?
explanation: Iterator is a generic interface that allows type-safe iteration.

title: JavaIterators - Q0040
text: Which of the following is true about Iterator and null elements?

options.text: Iterator can iterate over null elements

explanation: Iterator can iterate over null elements if the collection allows them.

title: JavaIterators - Q0041
text: Which of the following is true about Iterator and Map?

options.text: Map provides iterators for keys, values, and entries

explanation: Map provides iterators for keys, values, and entries through keySet(), values(), and entrySet().

title: JavaIterators - Q0042
text: Which of the following is true about Iterator and Set?

options.text: Set provides an iterator for unique elements
Set provides multiple iterators for duplicates

explanation: Set provides an iterator for unique elements since duplicates are not allowed.

title: JavaIterators - Q0043
text: Which of the following is true about Iterator and Queue?

options.text: Queue provides an iterator for its elements

explanation: Queue provides an iterator to traverse its elements in order.

title: JavaIterators - Q0044
text: Which of the following is true about Iterator and Deque?

options.text: Deque provides both forward and reverse iterators

explanation: Deque provides both forward and reverse iterators for traversal.

title: JavaIterators - Q0045
text: Which of the following is true about Iterator and ConcurrentHashMap?
explanation: ConcurrentHashMap provides fail-safe iterators that do not throw ConcurrentModificationException.

title: JavaIterators - Q0046
text: Which of the following is true about Iterator and remove() in fail-safe iterators?

options.text: remove() removes from the original collection

explanation: Fail-safe iterators do not support remove() because they operate on a copy of the collection.

title: JavaIterators - Q0047
text: Which of the following is true about Iterator and lambda expressions?
explanation: The forEachRemaining() method supports lambda expressions for iteration.

title: JavaIterators - Q0048
text: Which of the following is true about Iterator and Streams interoperability?

options.text: Streams can be created from Iterators using StreamSupport
Iterators cannot be converted to Streams

explanation: Streams can be created from Iterators using StreamSupport.stream().

title: JavaIterators - Q0049
text: Which of the following is true about Iterator and performance?

options.text: Iterator traversal is generally faster than for-each loop
Iterator traversal is slower than indexed access
Iterator traversal is always constant time

explanation: Iterator traversal is slower than indexed access for random-access lists like ArrayList.

title: JavaIterators - Q0050
text: Which of the following best describes the Iterator interface?

options.text: An interface for sequentially accessing elements of a collection

explanation: The Iterator interface provides a way to sequentially access elements of a collection.
